pace.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the speed at which something happens or is done
pace.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The pace of change in our lives is becoming faster and faster.
Public spending continues to rise at a steady pace.
pace.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the speed at which someone walks, runs, or moves
pace.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Lucy set off at a leisurely pace back to the hotel.
He quickened his pace, longing to be home.
Traffic slowed to a walking pace.
You need to step up the pace of your exercises.
pace.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a single step when you are running or walking, or the distance you move in one step
pace.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Rebecca walked a few paces behind her mum.
He took a pace towards the door.
pace.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The rapid pace of change creates uncertainty.
The pace of life in the countryside is slower.
The economy was growing at a slow but steady pace.
This allows each child to learn at his or her own pace.
Reform is proceeding at a snail’s pace.
Singapore prospered and modernized at a breakneck pace.
We worked at a hectic pace.
The pace of change is quickening.
After a surge in exports, the pace slackened considerably the following year.
Support for the campaign is gathering pace.
China's society is transforming but can it keep up the pace?
It’s essential that we constantly update our skills and keep up with the pace of change.
The pace of change accelerated dramatically in the early 1980s.
Here, the sun shines every day and the pace of life is slower.
The pace of development in computer graphics is amazing.
Some senior party figures favor a slower pace of reform.
pace.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to walk first in one direction and then in another many times, especially because you are nervous
pace.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I found Mark at the hospital, pacing restlessly up and down.
Sam stood up and paced the floor, deep in thought.
pace.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to measure a distance by walking across it with steps of equal length
pace.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The director paced out the length of the stage.
pace.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the rate or speed at which something happens
pace.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The average price of a new car began to soar at a faster pace than household incomes.
pace.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to change at the same rate as someone or something else
pace.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Next year’s spending may not even keep pace with inflation.
Demand continues to keep pace, with shipments rising about 2.5%.
pace.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to establish the speed at which your competitors try to do something, or the standard of quality they try to achieve
pace.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: It continues to set the pace for all other local shopping complexes.
